sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new record of the rare species
Mirocastnia pyrrhopygoides (Houlbert)
from Ecuador is reported, along with range extensions for
M. smalli (J. Y. Miller)
and
M. canis (Lathy)
. In addition, the genus
Mirocastnia J. Y. Miller
is revised and the diagnostic phenotypic characteristics of males and females, as well as male genitalia, are illustrated. Details on its natural history, biogeography, and biology are included with the purpose of solving the confusion in the taxonomy of the genus. All taxa previously considered to be species are herein relegated to subspecific status, i.e.
M. pyrrhopygoides canis
stat. nov.
and
M. p. smalli
stat. nov.

sec.title: Resumen
sec.p:
Se presenta un nuevo registro de la rara especie
Mirocastnia pyrrhopygoides (Houlbert)
proveniente de Ecuador , así como la ampliación del área de distribución de
M. smalli (J. Y. Miller)
y
M. canis (Lathy)
. Además, se revisa el género
Mirocastnia J. Y. Miller
, ilustrando las características fenotípicas diagnósticas de machos y hembras, así como de sus órganos genitales masculinos. Se incluyen detalles sobre historia natural, biogeografía y biología con el fin de resolver la confusión en la taxonomía del género. Todos los taxones considerados anteriormente como especies se relegan al estatus de subespecies, es decir,
M. pyrrhopygoides canis
stat. nov.
y
M. p. smalli
stat. nov.
Palabras clave: Mariposas-polilla gigantes, morfología, taxonomía

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
During a collecting trip at Otongachi Station, in Ecuador , from May to October 2017 , one of us (HT) received a particularly small lepidopteran from Mr. Italo Tapia. At first glance, it resembled a skipper, but after examining the specimen it became clear that it was a member of the Castniidae . Identifying the species became a challenge but consultation of several works dealing with the family enabled it to be determined as a female of
Mirocastnia pyrrhopygoides ( Houlbert, 1917 )
. Wanting to report this finding, HT asked for the help of JMG, who decided it would be a good idea to revise the genus and enlisted RW to continue their series of reviews of castniid genera (
,
,
).

This specimen ( Figs. 2K, L ) was found in Ecuador in the former Province of Pichincha , today Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas , Otongachi, Unión del Toachi, 00° 18’S – 78° 57’W , 01–30.VI.2017 . This is one of very few specimens to have been found recently in Ecuador and was collected about 500 km north of the type locality.

Mirocastnia
specimens have proved to be rather elusive, they are rarely found in collections, and
clearly states that at the time of describing the genus, only the type specimens were known to her. In her 1986 dissertation she also mentions a male of
M. pyrrhopygoides
collected by Curtis Callaghan in Valle del Cauca , Colombia (which we were unable to find in MGCL ). Years later,
presented information on
M. pyrrhopygoides
and listed one specimen from Colombia .
published general observations on the genus corroborating the similarity of
Mirocastnia
to Hesperiidae in the genera
Autochton Hübner, 1823
,
Celaenorrhinus Hübner, [1819]
, and
Paches Godman & Salvin, 1895
, as well as the sexual dimorphism in its three species. He also quoted
, who speculated that the female is a mimic of
Pythonides limaea (Hewitson, 1868)
, however, the resemblance of the two species is actually “extremely poor” (G. Lamas, pers. comm).
depict two specimens from Vinciguerra’s collection, a male
M. pyrrhopygoides
collected in Ecuador , in 2003, and a female
M. canis ( Lathy, 1923 )
from Peru , collected in 2006. These are the only specimens of
Mirocastnia
that we can find mentioned in the literature, previous to
and this work.

In recent years, a fair amount of dealers’ material of
M. canis
has become available from Huánuco , Peru , and more recently RW managed to procure series from Amazonas and Cuzco , Peru , which are major range extensions. All of these Peruvian specimens have been marketed as
M. pyrrhopygoides
but our investigations have proved them to be
M. canis
. Very few further specimens of
M. smalli J. Y. Miller, 1980
, from Panama have been recorded but we have become aware of a specimen of
M. smalli
collected in Costa Rica in 2002, the first record of the species from that country. Furthermore, another small number of specimens of
M. pyrrhopygoides
from Ecuador and Colombia have been found. However, specimens of this genus remain very rare in collections.

The three taxa considered within this genus are all very similar and the differences are not consistent, but the most evident difference between them is their size. Based on the larger group of specimens from different locations distributed in private and institutional collections that were available to us, there appears to be a geographical separation that might not necessarily be enough to reproductively isolate the three taxa. After studying all the specimens at our disposal and dissecting the genitalia of several males, we have concluded that there is no compelling justification for maintaining the three populations as separate species. Due to its scarcity and its habitat preferences, there is no doubt that the species is under-recorded. It is possible, that if many more geographically intermediate populations are found, it will prove to be a single long cline.

sec.title: Historical background
sec.p:
Mirocastnia pyrrhopygoides
was described by Houlbert, (1917) in the genus
Castnia Fabricius, 1807
, the genus in which virtually all Castniinae were included at the time. In his 1918 monograph, Houlbert then transferred the species to
Athis
(=
Hista Oiticica, 1955
). Shortly afterwards,
described
Castnia (Schaefferia) subcoerulea
as a species, but this was later found to be based on the first discovery of the female of
M. pyrrhopygoides
, which was originally described from the very dissimilar male.
Schaefferia
was created as a genus by
for the species
Papilio amycus (Cramer, 1779)
, this was later found to be preoccupied by
Schaefferia Absolon, 1900
and was replaced by
Feschaeria Oiticica, 1955
. Rothschild used this as a subgenus because he perceived similarities between
subcoerulea
and
amycus
. Shortly after this,
described his new species
canis
in the genus
Schaefferia
because of the similarities to Rothschild’s
subcoerulea
.

The most important work to date involving
Mirocastnia
is the review by J. Y.
. Her original intention was to describe the new species
M. smalli
from a female which she recognised as being related to
M. canis
. Subsequent material of
M. smalli
included a pair caught in copula , which enabled her to become the first person to recognise that
pyrrhopygoides
and
subcoerulea
were, in fact, male and female of the same species. After studying the type material of other taxa and recognising the remarkable sexual dimorphism, she created the new genus
Mirocastnia J. Y. Miller, 1980
for these species, with
M. smalli
as the type species (
;
).

In their phylogeny of the Neotropical
Castniidae, Moraes & Duarte (2014)
did not include
Mirocastnia
in their analysis due to lack of material. According to
Mirocastnia
, morphologically “lies in a somewhat intermediate position between
Feschaeria
and true
Hista ,
” adding that the general appearance, especially in the male hindwing, is characteristic of
H. boisduvalii (Walker, 1854)
, whereas the forewing maculation of both sexes is more similar to
Feschaeria .
However, genitalia characters show
Mirocastnia
to be separate from these two genera.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
Selected institutional and private collections worldwide containing specimens belonging to the genus
Mirocastnia
were examined. The number of specimens studied (77) is the largest compared to previously published works on the genus.

As well as using wing colour patterns and geographic distribution to establish separate species or subspecies, we dissected the male genitalia of some specimens at our disposal. We followed

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Habitus

Superficially, this genus is similar to several Neotropical Hesperiidae , the reddish hair tuft at the tip of the abdomen is characteristic of the skipper subfamily Pyrrhopyginae .
Mirocastnia
are highly sexually dimorphic, and the taxa are very similar to each other. The male dorsal forewing base colour is light brown, whilst the female base colour is a darker brown.A yellowish semi-hyaline transverse band is found in males, whilst in females a similar whitish band is present. A subapical spot band is also found on both male and female forewings, which is always creamy white in males but tends to be yellowish in females. Even though sexual dimorphism can be detected in the forewing, hindwings provide more obvious clues. Males have a tawny overscaling along the costal margin, extending toward the lateral margin. Females, however, show an iridescent metallic pale blue patch along the discal cell, broadening toward the costal margin on one side, and pointing toward the tornus on the other. At the edge of the iridescent metallic patch, closer to the anal margin, are two creamy-white spots. Two postdiscal creamy-white spots are also present. There are similar spots in the same position on the male hindwings, but they are yellowish. Ventrally, the wings exhibit a similar pattern to the dorsal one. The males’ wings have an overscaling that varies from rust to tawny, while females show bright blue overscaling basad, of a variable size. The abdomen coloration also helps to discern the sexes, being light brown in males and dark brown in females. At the tip of the abdomen, males exhibit a tuft of large tawny scales, while in the females the apical tuft of the abdomen is reddish. Wing veins are covered with slightly larger scales.
There are minor differences between the three subspecies, but they are not always consistent, so the only way to be certain as to which subspecies a specimen belongs, is its provenance.

The most notable difference in the external morphology of the three recognised taxa of this genus is their size. The range of forewing lengths for specimens examined of each taxon is as follows:
M. smalli
♁: 19–26mm , ♀ : 19–29mm ;
M. pyrrhopygoides
♁: 25–34mm , ♀ : 27–30mm ;
M. canis
♁: 21–29mm , ♀ : 22–35mm . ( Figs. 1 to 4)

The genitalia of the three taxa in the genus are highly similar, with the main difference being their size. The genital capsule possesses a single uncus with socii slightly developed. All taxa in the genus possess a bifurcate gnathos. Valva, in general, is lobate along the costal margin and has a pronounced cleft that is recurved close to the sacculus. The aedeagus is moderately curved, and slightly tapered. It is also sclerotised with a dorsal sclerotised plate. Vesica is extruded in dextral view in all three taxa.

sec.title: Foodplants and habits
sec.p:
Little is known of the genus in nature, but it appears to occur mainly in montane and cloud forests.
writes of
M. smalli
that most of the specimens collected were taken in a semi-cloud forest habitat. According to the collector, Gordon B. Small Jr., the specimens were collected near the top of a mountain which rises to
980 m .
The forest is comprised of the fan palm
Colpothrinax cookii Robert W. Read
( Arecaceae ) and various trees with moss cover, in addition to several Bromeliaceae , with
Chusquea sp.
and
Olyra standleyi Hitchcock
( Poaceae ) in the understory. The butterfly fauna in general is depauperate with some
Pedaliodes
(Satyrinae) and
Argyrogrammana
( Riodinidae ). Specimens of
smalli
are found on the wing from March to August. The general flight pattern is quite similar to some Hesperiidae . They rest and alight frequently on bare twigs and the fronds of
C. cookii
. Although they have been associated with various species of palms, the distribution of
Colpothrinax
does not coincide with that of
Mirocastnia
. Small has observed a female of
M. smalli
frequenting a bromeliad high in these palms (
,
). José Antonio (Toño) Azofeifa , a parataxonomist from the old INBio, found and successfully reared an
M. smalli
larva in a bromeliad in Costa Rica (Bernardo Espinoza, pers. comm.). Thus, Bromeliaceae would appear to be the larval foodplant for
M. smalli
and the other two taxa in the genus.

states that the flight period of
Mirocastnia
is from March to August, with most specimens being collected in March, although we have records of specimens being caught from March to November. They are diurnal, normally flying between 11:00 and 12:30, and the perching behaviour is similar to
Feschaeria
, landing with both pairs of wings stretched out or barely reflexed, but not in the stegopterous position, on bare twigs in full sun (
).

mentions that
M. pyrrhopygoides
is found at high altitudes ( 1500–2000 m .), although it is not known where he came by this information. It is very likely that this was based on
ssp. canis
from Huánuco rather than
ssp. pyrrhopygoides
as specimens have recently been available from Peruvian dealers. Unfortunately, the data from these dealers are not always reliable and rarely carry altitudinal data. Most of these specimens carry the data Tingo María, Carpish or Mallqui, all of which are in Huánuco department. Carpish and Mallqui do seem to be reasonable localities as they are in cloud forest and at reasonably high altitudes; Tingo María (
670 m .
) is likely to be a generic area designation, being the nearest town. However, the series from Amazonas and Cuzco do have reliable data; the Amazonas ones were caught at 800 and 1800 m ., those from Cuzco at 657 and
980 m .
The few specimens of
ssp. pyrrhopygoides
from Ecuador and Colombia that have altitudinal data were caught between 800 and 1000 m . Subspecies
smalli
has been found between 760 and 1405 m .

tp:treatment-sec.p:
“
Schaefferia canis , sp. n.
” Lathy, 1923 : Annals and Magazine of natural History (9) 12 (68): 225–226. (
,
).
Type locality: The locality label reads: Rio Perené, Peru (Watkins). This is in the Chanchamayo region of Junín department, Peru.

Taxonomic status: A subspecies of
M. pyrrhopygoides ( Houlbert, 1917 )
stat. nov. Lathy (1923) originally described it as a species in the genus
Schaefferia Houlbert, 1918
, following Rothschild (1919) . Miller (1980) transferred it to her new genus
Mirocastnia
, a combination subsequently followed by Miller (1995) and Lamas (1995) .

Male genitalia : (
) Despite the size of most specimens, the male genitalia look miniaturised when compared with castniids of most other genera. Saccus is reduced. Valvae elongate along costa with a prominent cleft along sacculus. Juxta is sclerotised. Aedeagus sclerotised, moderately curved, barely contorted. We did not examine the female genitalia, but it is worth noting that Miller (1980) separated
M. canis
from the other two taxa in the group by stating that “The pleural setal patch dorsad is more prominent and denser than in either
smalli
or
pyrrhopygoides
with the sclerotised pattern associated with the ostium bursae diagnostic” and also “Additional setae are found along lamella postvaginalis than in either
pyrrhopygoides
or
smalli .
”

The subspecies therefore seems to be restricted to Peru and is currently only known from Amazonas, San Martín, Huánuco, Junín, and Cuzco departments (
).

Discussion: When writing his original description Lathy (1923) only had the female holotype of
subcoerulea ( Rothschild, 1919 )
(
) with which to compare his specimen, more material is now available for comparison. The differences given by Lathy are that the abdomen of
subcoerulea
is entirely black whereas that of
canis
is white below with the anal segments orange. The abdomens on both specimens are now missing, presumably removed by Miller for genitalia dissection for her 1980 work, they have since been returned and dissection labels have been added. The likelihood is that the
subcoerulea
abdomen was only black due to heavy greasing, a very common occurrence in Castniidae . The other difference that Lathy gave is that
subcoerulea
lacks the marginal red patches on the dorsal hindwing. Indeed, the
canis
type does have faint rust-red submarginal patches between the veins on the hindwing (
). This was considered to be the defining characteristic of the species, but recent material makes it seem unlikely to be anything more than an individual aberrant form. We have seen no specimens from Huánuco that have this feature but some females from Cuzco exhibit it, albeit much less pronounced.

Miller (1980) further states that “The very prominent iridescent powder blue patch basad on hindwing below conveniently separates
canis
from
pyrrhopygoides
and
smalli
”. This does seem to be the defining feature of females as all specimens from Peru have this large powder-blue patch on the ventral hindwing (
). Specimens of
M. pyrrhopygoides
and
M. smalli
seem to have a much-reduced patch or merely a sprinkling of blue scales (
,
), although this can sometimes be obscured by greasing of the very few specimens known. It also seems that the forewing transverse semi-hyaline band is narrower than in the other subspecies.

Even though the male of this subspecies has not been mentioned in the literature before, it is now quite wellknown. Males from Peru do show consistent small differences from
M. p. pyrrhopygoides
from Ecuador and Colombia. In fact, they are more similar in appearance to
smalli
from Panama than they are to
pyrrhopygoides
sharing all the main characteristics (see
smalli
), except that they are usually considerably larger.

The recent dealers’ material from Peru has all been marketed as
M. pyrrhopygoides
. The female feature of the ventral basal blue patch pointed out by Miller (1980) , and the slight differences in the male phenotypes, show that all known Peruvian specimens, with the exception of the Amazonas specimen from the border with Ecuador, are in fact
ssp. canis
.

A particular feature of this subspecies is the very wide size range in specimens of both sexes. In the series from Huánuco in coll. RW, forewing lengths range from 21mm to 29mm for males and 22mm to 35mm for females (
), this could be a result of the altitude at which the specimens were collected.

The taxon was so named because Lathy (1923) thought that the pattern of the pale blue markings on the dorsal hindwing of the holotype resembles the pattern of a dog’s head, similar to the forewing of the pierid genus
Zerene Hübner, [1819]
.

Type material: Described from three male syntypes collected by Marc Hüe de Mathan (1843–1917) in 1891. At the time of description, the specimens were in the collection of Charles Oberthür (1845–1924), they are now in NHMUK . Miller (1980) designated one of these syntypes as lectotype (
), the other two become paralectotypes.

Type locality: Zaruma , Ecuador . Zaruma is a town in El Oro province , the co-ordinates are 03°41′S , 79°36′W , elevation 1,200m
.

Taxonomic status: A valid species. Originally described in the genus
Castnia Fabricius, 1807
, as were nearly all Castniinae at the time, Houlbert (1918) then listed it in
Athis Hübner, [1819]
. Miller (1980) transferred it to her new genus
Mirocastnia
, a combination subsequently followed by Miller (1995) and Lamas (1995) .

Male genitalia : (Fig, 7D, E) The male genitalia are very similar to the other subspecies, and like them look miniaturised when compared with most Castniidae . Saccus is reduced. Valvae elongate along costa with a noticeable cleft along sacculus. Juxta is sclerotised. Aedeagus moderately curved, slightly recurved and sclerotised.

Distribution: This subspecies is known from central Colombia to southern Ecuador and northern Peru . We know of records from Risaralda and Valle del Cauca departments in Colombia , and Esmeraldas , Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas , El Oro , Morona Santiago and Zamora Chinchipe in Ecuador , and Amazonas province in Peru (
).

Discussion: This appears to be a rare subspecies, known only from a handful of specimens. When Miller (1980) described the genus only the types were known to her, since then only a few more specimens have been found. In recent years a reasonable number of dealers’ specimens marketed as
M. pyrrhopygoides
have been available from Huánuco in Peru , but these are referable to
ssp. canis
.
One noticeable feature of many males of this subspecies is that there is an overscaling of dark scales on the forewing which makes the transverse semi-hyaline band seem less evident.
The species was so named because of its resemblance to species in the Hesperiidae subfamily Pyrrhopyginae .

tp:treatment-sec.p:
“
Mirocastnia smalli
, new species ” J. Y. Miller, 1980 : Bulletin of the Allyn Museum 60 : 11–14, figs. (
).

Type material: Described from a male holotype (
), six male and four female paratypes, all the types are in MGCL ( González, 2023 ). The type series was collected by Gordon B. Small Jr. ( Miller, 1980 ).

Type locality:
The holotype was collected at Cerro Jefe , a mountain in Panama province , Panama , just south of the Chagres National Park
.

Taxonomic status: A subspecies of
M. pyrrhopygoides ( Houlbert, 1917 )
stat. nov.
This is the type species of the genus, also listed in this combination by Miller (1995) and Lamas (1995) .

Male genitalia: (Fig, 7F, G) Genital capsule with a single uncus, socii are slightly developed. Gnathos bifurcate. Valva elongate along the costal margin. A pronounced recurved cleft is present by the sacculus. Saccus is reduced. Juxta is moderately sclerotised.The aedeagus is slightly curved, barely recurved, moderately sclerotised. It possesses a dorsal sclerotised plate.

Discussion: The overall appearance of this subspecies is darker and smaller than
M. p. pyrrhopygoides
. The male is especially dark along the tornus of the hindwing on both surfaces. The two pairs of pale postdiscal spots are also more contrasted in
smalli
than in
pyrrhopygoides
. In the female, the blue patch on the hindwing is even more reduced than it is in
pyrrhopygoides
on both surfaces. In both sexes, the forewing transverse semi-hyaline band seems to be slightly wider than in
pyrrhopygoides
. However, these features are variable in all subspecies so are merely an average. Much more material of
Mirocastnia
is known now than was available to Miller when she wrote her 1980 paper, which shows that the features she selected to separate her species do not always hold true in longer series.
The subspecies was named after its discoverer, Gordon Burgess Small, Jr. (1934–1989).

“

,
sp. nov.
” Rothschild, 1919 : Novitates zoologicae 26 (1): 18. (
).

Type material: Described from a single female which is the holotype by monotypy (
). This holotype was in the collection of Lionel Walter Rothschild (1868–1937), it is now in NHMUK .
Type locality: Rothschild (1919) only gave the type locality as Ecuador , and this is all that is mentioned on the label data of the specimen. This cannot now be further restricted.

Taxonomic status: A junior subjective synonym of
M. pyrrhopygoides ( Houlbert, 1917 )
. Originally described as a species in the genus
Castnia ( Schaefferia )
, it was synonymised with
M. pyrrhopygoides
by Miller (1980) .
Male genitalia : Not relevant.
Distribution: Not relevant.

Discussion: Houlbert (1917) described
M. pyrrhopygoides
from three males ; Rothschild’s
subcoerulea
was the first description of the female, which is quite different from the male and was not at the time recognised as being the same species; this problem was exacerbated by the fact that the male and female were placed in different genera by their authors. Miller (1980) was the first to recognise their conspecificity.
